moves.6... b5: In the pirc, black, usually attacks white' kingside
moves.9. Qd2: White masses a huge amount of material in the center
moves.9... O-O: This could have wait, 9. c5 or 9. Bb7 might  have been better but I was afraid of 10. Bh6
moves.10. Ne2: To open the diagonal for the queen and/or prepare  a further Nf4
moves.10... c5: I estimate that it's hard time to attack the queenside as the many pieces white has but d4 is overprotected.
moves.11. c3: providing an escape for the LSB
moves.12... d5: Black attack had better to be strong because of the many troops, white has massed toward the black king
moves.13... c4: I didn't see what else I could do. It closes the game but white is better on the center and has all his lesser pieces and the queen aiming at black's  castle
moves.14. Bc2: White plaid very well until now and has positionnal advantage
moves.14... f6: !? I felt cramped and thought, I had to do something. It's a mistake of course? Maybe due to lack of patience...
moves.15. exf6 Rxf6: At least, the pawn exchange has released pressure on f6
moves.19. Nxg6 Qd6: The black king is weak and black is in late of material. The 2 good things are  that black has a better control on the center and can quickly bring all his reserves to protect the king.
moves.20... Nf8: Black has to bring as many pieces as possible to protect the king.
moves.22. Re3: The rook will soon come to g3 or h3
moves.22... Bc6: So that the a rook can come on a7 to protect g7
moves.24. Nf4: Some more air but black is still besieged
moves.25... Bxh5: Now black is no longer in late of material but still besieged
moves.26. f3: It's Verdun ! And to break the siege, the Allied drove a strong attack on the Somme.
moves.26... Rb7: So that I plan a counterattack on the right wing to force white to remove his LSB from the b1 h7 diagonal
moves.28. b3 cxb3: To force the LSB to leave the diagonal
moves.29. Bxb3 Ng6: Black's plan is now to get rid of the dangerous e knight
moves.30... Ne7: menacing 31. Nf5 with fork attack on both rook and queen
moves.31. Bc2: But the bishop is back ! The counterattack failed
moves.31... Kf8: king off the g file and on a black square
moves.34. Qf4 h5:
The situation is very complicated now but black has massed almost all his pieces in front of his king and white is outnumbered.
In the following trade, black will probably lose some material but black is in advance and firing the e knight is worth a pawn.
moves.37. Rxh5: Now white is only one pawn down but black's position is better
moves.38. Rc1 b4: If the c pawn falls, the d pawn will follow and black will get one passed pawn.
moves.39. axb4 axb4 40. Ba4: I didn't understand the point of this move
moves.42. Bc2: Attacking the rook and blocking the passed c pawn
moves.42... Rh6: In this position and with material advantage, I estimate that the trade was valuable for black
moves.43. Rxh6 Bxh6: White's d pawn can wait, it is doomed anyway
moves.44. Kf2 Nb5: To attack the d pawn and prevent the king to come on help
moves.46. Kd3 Nxc2: The trade seems to be good for black
moves.47. Kxc2 d4: Now the white king has to stay on d3 or e2
moves.48. h4 Be3: The pawns must be attacked from behind
moves.50. h5 Be3 51. Kd3 Kg7: White resigns here, for he is almost in zugzwang (he can only play Kc2 or Kd3 cannot prevent the black king to come on g3 and take the pawns one by one
